thread.title_full: Guidelines Updated After 50 Infections Linked to Scopes

author: Rebecca Rudolph, Editor, Surgical Products
title: Guidelines Updated After 50 Infections Linked to Scopes
text:
Bronchoscopes have been liked to 50 infections in the last year, and the Food and Drug Administration (FDA) has updated guidelines to reflect these preventable cases.
These reminders come after an FDA investigation of the cases which found two recurrent themes:
Failure to meticulously follow manufacturer instructions for reprocessing Continued use of devices despite integrity, maintenance and mechanical issues. Updated guidelines for bronchoscopes were released on Sept. 17 and include a reminder to:
Follow manufacturer reprocessing and storage instructions to the letter, in addition to recommendations for preventative maintenance and repair. Immediately replace or repair any bronchoscopes that fail a leak test or show signs of damage. Implement a quality control program for reprocessing departments. The Associated Press says about 500,000 bronchoscope procedures are performed every year, so while the 50 cases are small fraction of the total procedures, they were preventable.
Infections linked to scopes have been a subject of concern recently, but most cases garnering attention were liked to tainted duodenoscopes. Numerous patients filed lawsuits against facilities and manufacturers for infections they attribute to the devices.
